results.title: Ashputtle: or the mother's ghost
results.brief_description: A mother does what has to be done to help her daughter - even if it means returning from the grave. A retelling of a traditional folktale (Grimm’s ‘Ashputtle’ as reworked by Angela Carter). Ashputtle is an unloved, uncared for and barely human child until her dead mother rises from the grave to look after her. It is a beautifully cut-out animation that explores themes of identity, responsibility, disintegration and transformation, in a bold and vibrant visual style.

results.title: Brother
results.brief_description: The childhood memory of a brother, his cigarette butts, asthma and head lice. An exploration of the simple truths and ironies that make up a life. An iconic Australian film.

results.title: Catch of the day
results.creator_credit: Sarah Watt, Australian Film Commission and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: The bright, beautiful and spontaneous ocean is something to wallow in. A young girl plays in the ocean and with the fishes. A dashing surfer rides up on his white steed and declares ‘I’ve come - you’ll never have to chop onions again!’ Jane wakes up from her dream (or was it a nightmare?) Working at the fish market, she endures the sexual innuendo and double entendres from male customers and fellow workers alike. When matters come to a head, she cleverly takes the situation into her own hands and offers a unique solution to unsolicited sexual advances… An impressionistic animation.

results.title: Cousin
results.brief_description: The childhood remembrance of a cousin, his special arm, pet rocks and shopping trolley. He was born with cerebral palsy. The narrator tells of their antics together as children: their attempts to fly off the chook shed roof, out of control shopping trolley rides as well as being introduced to his many assorted collections of tee shirts, pet rocks and toenails.

results.title: Blow-up
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: ‘Blow up’ is a visual pun. Austrian experimental film-maker, Siegfried Fruhauf, uses discovered footage of a man demonstrating mouth to mouth resuscitation on celluloid. The film is displayed in a way that show-cases the celluloid format as an object, rather than viewing the film with the content frame by frame. As the footage rolls the film is objectively abstracted with penetrating sounds of heavy breathing. As the ‘camera’ pans closer, the image takes over and we enter the film. It is our breath that now fills the image.

results.title: Kitchen sink
results.brief_description: A woman finds an unidentified root growing out of her kitchen sink plug hole. The umbilical like vine grows into an adult male covered in hair from head to toe. The woman shaves the catatonic man and the two begin to play out a primal scene of lust and longing. Alison Maclean’s perverse horror recasts desire in its most primordial and visceral guise.

results.title: The Golden Dark Age of Reason
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: An exploration of the beauty of New York’s classically inspired architecture; the Chrysler Building, a blimp passing over the Brooklyn Bridge, a young boy performing backflips on a street corner.

results.title: Bare
results.creator_credit: Deborah Strutt, Liz Baulch, Wild Iris Productions and Amanda Roberts
results.brief_description: There are misunderstandings aplenty in this award-winning Australian short when 2 gay boys accidentally catch their lesbian neighbours in an early morning clinch. High density living in all its revealing glory.
